HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to control keyboard input and screen feedback. Experienced users may prefer to have keyboard echo off or set to words only, where new users may find it helpful to hear characters spoken while typing. Typing echo and typing interruption are examples of keyboard input. Screen feedback examples are screen echo and progress bar announcement.

Controls.Label: &Progress Bar Updates Announcement
Controls.HelpMsg: Programs often use progress bars to show the status of a process, such as an installation. Select an interval in this list to determine how often JAWS announces the state of progress bars during a process. Select "Announce All" if you want JAWS to read progress bars as changes occur. Select "Off" if you do not want to hear progress bar information. The default is to announce progress bar updates at 5 second Intervals.

Controls.Label: Typing &Echo
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to determine how much feedback is received when typing and pressing keys. You may choose either characters, words, both characters and words, or none so that JAWS remains silent as you type. Character Echo is the default. You can toggle Typing Echo settings by pressing INSERT+2. This allows you to cycle through the different options without using Settings Center.

Controls.Label: &Screen Echo
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to determine how much text is read when information on the screen changes. This includes highlighted text, all text as it appears, or no speech echo as text appears or changes on screen. The default setting is Echo Highlighted Text. Changing the Screen Echo setting may affect the reading of menus and other items. For this reason, it is recommended that you only make Screen Echo changes in application-specific settings files.

Controls.Label: &Typing Interrupt
Controls.HelpMsg: Clear this check box to have JAWS continue speaking information from the last command, even if you press keys such as letters or numbers.  Pressing CTRL will still interrupt speech. Using keystrokes to interrupt speech frees JAWS to begin speaking text from the most recent command. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Insert Key Mode
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, the INSERT key functions as a sticky key. Any key pressed immediately after pressing the INSERT key is treated as if it were pressed in combination with the INSERT key. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: &Key Repeat
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, a key that is held down is repeated. For example, if you are editing a document and need to insert a row of dashes to separate sections of text, just press and hold down the dash key to quickly type a series of dashes. Clearing this control prevents accidental repeating of characters. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Sho&w Virtual Viewer on Screen
Controls.HelpMsg: Select to have the Virtual Viewer visually display on the screen when INSERT+F1 and other helpful messages are accessed. This is useful in training environments. However, in a presentation application like PowerPoint, displaying the Virtual Viewer can disrupt the presentation. JAWS functions the same in these messages whether or not the Virtual Viewer is displayed.

Controls.Label: Enable Virtual Cursor for Windows Universal Apps
Controls.HelpMsg:
If this check box is selected, the Virtual PC Cursor is used to read Windows universal apps. When using the Virtual PC Cursor, Windows universal apps are presented in a manner similar to web pages, enabling you to interact with these apps as if you were navigating a web page in a browser. Windows universal Apps are usually obtained from the Microsoft Store, however some come pre-installed as part of Windows.
This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: &Lower audio volume of programs while JAWS speaks
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, audio from other programs will be reduced while JAWS is speaking. This is commonly referred to as audio ducking. This check box is cleared by default and is only available in Windows 8 and later. You can also press INSERT+SPACEBAR, followed by D to toggle audio ducking on or off.

Controls.Label: Avoid speech cut off when using &Bluetooth headphones or some sound cards
Controls.HelpMsg:
Many modern Bluetooth headphones and speakers shut down after a while of not receiving sound to conserve battery. If this check box is selected, JAWS will keep them awake by constantly playing silence. You will not hear anything, but your device will remain active, resulting in more consistent speech. Note that the battery of your headphones/speakers could drain faster if you turn this on.
This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: &Notification Rules Enabled
Controls.HelpMsg:
The JAWS Notification History, INSERT+SPACEBAR, followed by N, displays a history of notifications received from Windows and applications during the past 24 hours while JAWS or Fusion was running. Using this manager, you can easily define rules for all the various notifications to personalize how much, or how little you want in both Speech and Braille for each notification in the future. For example, you may want JAWS to announce notifications from Outlook only if they include specific text, or play a specific sound instead of interrupting you with a spoken message.
Clear this check box to turn off all user-created rules for notifications. Once disabled, you will not be able to create any rules for the selected notification in the list, and JAWS or Fusion will announce all notifications as they are received.
This check box is selected by default.

HelpMsg: Forms Mode is needed when working with HTML content in a browser and you need to input information. Since JAWS uses a “Virtual Mode” to navigate, you can normally press letters to navigate between Headings, Paragraphs, Tables, etc. But when you need to type in text or use the ARROW keys to select items in a Combo Box, you need another mode referred to as Forms Mode. Use the options in this group to configure Forms Mode operation.

Controls.Label: &Select Forms Mode
Controls.HelpMsg:
Use the radio buttons in this group to select how you wish to get in and out of Forms Mode.
When set to Auto, JAWS automatically enters Forms Mode when you press TAB, SHIFT+TAB, or the ARROW keys to move to a control that requires Forms Mode in order to interact with it, such as an edit field or combo box. To indicate you have entered Forms Mode, you will hear a "pop" sound, or you can use the status cells in Braille. When you finish working with a control, you can press ESC to exit Forms Mode, or press UP or DOWN ARROW to move away from the control and exit Forms Mode. This functionality can be very useful for new and sighted JAWS users and is the default setting.
Selecting Manual prevents JAWS from ever putting you into forms mode as you navigate using any of the commands including the TAB Key. This means that when you move into an edit field or combo box control, you must press ENTER first to type text or select a value. To manually exit Forms Mode, press NUM PAD PLUS or ESC.
Semi-auto is a mode in between Auto and Manual. You will only enter Forms Mode if you land on a control while navigating with TAB or SHIFT+TAB. Forms Mode will not be activated if you navigate with the ARROW keys or Navigation Quick Keys. You must manually exit Forms Mode when Semi-auto is active. Semi-auto and Manual Forms Mode may be better suited for experienced users, or when using Smart Navigation.
Note: When Forms Mode is on, Say Line or Say All reads all text on the current line. This includes labels and descriptions.

Controls.Label: Auto Forms Mode Settings
Controls.HelpMsg: When using Navigation Quick Keys to move about a form, use this group to set the  delay between a form control becoming active, and you being able to type or select a  form control option. This group is only available when using Auto Forms Mode.

Controls.Label: Navigation &Quick Key Delay
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this combo box to set the amount of delay before Forms Mode becomes active when using Navigation Quick Keys to move to the next control. For example, if the delay is 3 seconds, and you press E to move to the next edit box, Forms Mode does not turn on until this interval passes. You will then hear an announcement stating that Forms Mode is on, which means that you can now type in the edit box. Delays range from 0.5 seconds to 5 seconds and Never. Never is the default setting, which means that you must press ENTER to start Forms Mode after moving to a control with Navigation Quick Keys. The Navigation Quick Key Delay option is only available when configured for Auto Forms Mode.

Controls.Label: &Manual Forms Mode Settings
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this group to choose what happens when content on the current HTML page is  updated or refreshed while in Forms Mode. This group is only available when using Manual Forms Mode.

Controls.Label: Disable Forms Mode when a New page loads
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this check box to determine what happens when content on the current HTML page is updated or refreshed while in Forms Mode. When selected, a page refresh or update will automatically exit Forms Mode.  When cleared, Forms Mode remains active regardless of a page refresh or update. The check box is selected by default.  This option is only available when configured for Manual Forms Mode.

Controls.Label: Forms Mo&de Sounds
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to control and select WAV files to indicate when focus  moves in and out of a form control.

Controls.Label: Enable Sound &Notifications
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to make the options in the Forms Mode Sounds group available. Clear this check box if you do not want to hear WAV file sounds and would prefer to hear traditional spoken messages. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Select Sound for &Entering Forms Mode...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to open a list of available WAV files to indicate when you enter a form control. This option is not available if the Enable Sounds Notifications check box is cleared. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Select Sound for &Leaving Forms Mode...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to open a list of available WAV files to indicate when you exit a form field. This option is not available if the Enable Sound Notifications check box is cleared. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: List1
Controls.HelpMsg: Select a WAV file to use as the sound that indicates when you enter or exit a form field.

Controls.Label: &Play
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Play to hear a sample of the selected WAV file.

Controls.Label: Brow&se...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Browse to search your computer for a WAV file to use to indicate when focus enters and exits a form field.

Controls.Label: OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to control where and how JAWS inserts a slight pause between lines, sentences, and paragraphs when reading with Say All.

Controls.Label: Say All &Reads
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to define where and how JAWS pauses while reading with Say All. Select the With Pauses, Line at a Time radio button to add a slight pause at the end of a line. Select the Without Pauses, Line at a Time radio button for smoother reading. Select the Sentence at a Time radio button for applications in which Say All reading sounds choppy. This will add pauses to the end of sentences and make the reading sound smoother. Select the Paragraph at a Time radio button when reading large documents. This allows you to press the RIGHT SHIFT key to quickly move through the paragraphs without needing to interrupt Say All reading.

Controls.Label: With pauses, Line at a time
Without pauses, Line at a time
Say All Scheme
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to select and use a speech and sound scheme for Say All reading. You can also use the Add/Remove button in this group to add or delete a factory Say All scheme to the list of available schemes.

Controls.Label: Select Sc&heme
Controls.HelpMsg: This option allows you to load a different scheme to use during Say All reading. It applies only to HTML and Word documents. The Say All Text With Sounds scheme speaks the text of links and headings, but plays a subtle sound instead of announcing links and headings. The Say All Text Only scheme gives no indication of links and headings, it merely speaks the text of the links and headings. Note that you can also use the Add/Remove button to add and delete other schemes for use with Say All Reading. The default for Select Scheme is No Change.

Controls.Label: A&dd/Remove
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Add/Remove to open the Select Say All Schemes dialog box. It contains a list of factory speech and sound schemes that you can add to or remove from the Say All Scheme group. To add a scheme to the list, select its check box and choose OK. To remove a scheme from the list, clear its check box and choose OK. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Say &Blank Lines during Say All
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to announce blank lines when reading with Say All. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: Indicate &Caps during Say All
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have JAWS indicate capitalization when reading with Say All. Capitalized text is spoken using a higher pitch. This check box is cleared by default.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure braille settings.
Use the options in this group to define how text attributes, such as bold, italic, underline, and so on, are represented on a braille display.

Controls.Label: Braille Marking
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this group to select the text attributes that you want to identify for a block of text on the braille display. These attributes include highlight, bold, underline, italic, strikeout, color, and script defined markings. The Highlight check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Highlight
Controls.HelpMsg: Select to mark highlighted text on the braille display.

Controls.Label: &Bold
Controls.HelpMsg: Select to mark bold text on the braille display.

Controls.Label: &Underline
Controls.HelpMsg: Select to mark underline text on the braille display.

Controls.Label: &Italic
Controls.HelpMsg: Select to mark italic text on the braille display.

Controls.Label: &Strikeout
Controls.HelpMsg: Select to mark strikethrough text on the braille display.

Controls.Label: S&cript Defined Markings
Controls.HelpMsg: If this check box is selected, any attributes defined within scripts are represented as attributes.

Controls.Label: C&olor
Controls.HelpMsg: If this check box is selected, any colors you have defined to be represented in braille are identified as an attribute.

Controls.Label: &Define Braille Color Marking...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Define Braille Color Marking to open the Braille Color Markings dialog box. Use it to select a foreground color for the text attributes. You must select the Color check box before you can gain access to this button. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Dot Pattern Values
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this group to modify the braille dot patterns that identify text attributes. Each digit in the edit box represents a dot on a refreshable braille display. For example, DOTS 1-2 indicates bold text. DOTS 1-2-5 indicates highlighted text.

Controls.Label: Hi&ghlight Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Type a dot pattern for the highlight attribute. The default is DOTS 1-2-5.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Bo&ld Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Type a dot pattern for the bold attribute. The default is DOTS 1-2. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: U&nderline Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Type a dot pattern for the underline attribute. The default is DOTS 1-3-6. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: I&talic Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Type a dot pattern for the italic attribute. The default is DOTS 2-4.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Stri&keout Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Type a dot pattern for the strikethrough attribute. The default is DOTS 2-3-4.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Extra &Markings Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Type a dot pattern for the extra markings attribute. The default is DOTS 1-5.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: No&rmal Text Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Type a dot pattern for the normal text attribute. The default is DOTS 1-3-4-5.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Attribut&e Rotation Rate:
Controls.HelpMsg: In Attribute Mode, all attributes assigned to a block of text are indicated. When multiple attributes are assigned to the same block of text, the braille display cycles through each of them. Use this combo box to set the rate, in milliseconds, at which this cycling occurs.

Controls.Label: &Add...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to add an item from the Available To list to the Show On list.

Controls.Label: &OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

HelpMsg: JAWS provides many ways to access information and navigate within Windows. The cursor you use to access Windows determines what information JAWS reads. Use the options in this group to configure the dot pattern, state, and blink rate for the PC Cursor, JAWS Cursor, and Invisible Cursor.

Controls.Label: &PC Cursor
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure the dot pattern, state, and blink rate for the PC Cursor. It is the primary cursor used by JAWS, and it corresponds to the system focus. Use it to navigate menus, edit text in documents, and navigate dialog boxes.

Controls.Label: &Dot Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Use to specify a dot pattern for the PC Cursor. Each digit in the edit box represents a dot on a refreshable Braille display. The default setting is DOTS 7-8.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Cursor State
Controls.HelpMsg: Select a radio button in this group to set the dots for the PC Cursor to always remain up, always remain down, or raise and lower at a set increment known as the blink rate. The default is to use a blinking cursor.

Controls.Label: &Blink Rate
Controls.HelpMsg: Sets the speed in milliseconds at which the PC Cursor on the braille display blinks. To indicate a blinking cursor, the dots raise and lower at regular intervals. Using different blinking rates for each cursor can help you determine which cursor is active. The default is 500.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: &JAWS Cursor
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure the dot pattern, state, and blink rate for the JAWS Cursor. It is useful when working with Windows, and it corresponds to the system mouse. Use it to manipulate the system mouse, read static text, obtain an overview of information that appears on the screen, and access other parts of Windows to which the PC Cursor cannot access.

Controls.Label: D&ot Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Use to specify a dot pattern for the JAWS Cursor. Each digit in the edit box represents a dot on a refreshable Braille display. The default setting is DOTS 7-8.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Cursor State
Controls.HelpMsg: Select a radio button in this group to set the dots for the JAWS Cursor to always remain up, always remain down, or raise and lower at a set increment known as the blink rate. The default is to use a blinking cursor.

Controls.Label: B&link Rate
Controls.HelpMsg: Sets the speed in milliseconds at which the JAWS Cursor on the braille display blinks. To indicate a blinking cursor, the dots raise and lower at regular intervals. Using different blinking rates for each cursor can help you determine which cursor is active. The default is 500.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: I&nvisible Cursor
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure the dot pattern, state, and blink rate for the Invisible Cursor. It allows you to move around the screen without changing the position of the PC Cursor or mouse pointer. Use it to read text and access options that you cannot move to with the PC Cursor. You can also use the Invisible Cursor to provide a quick overview of information currently available on the screen.

Controls.Label: Do&t Pattern
Controls.HelpMsg: Use to specify a dot pattern for the Invisible Cursor. Each digit in the edit box represents a dot on a refreshable Braille display. The default setting is DOTS 7-8.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Cursor State
Controls.HelpMsg: Select a radio button in this group to set the dots for the Invisible Cursor to always remain up, always remain down, or raise and lower at a set increment known as the blink rate. The default is to use a blinking cursor.

Controls.Label: Bl&ink Rate
Controls.HelpMsg: Sets the speed in milliseconds at which the Invisible Cursor on the braille display blinks. To indicate a blinking cursor, the dots raise and lower at regular intervals. Using different blinking rates for each cursor can help you determine which cursor is active. The default is 500.  Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

HelpMsg: Braille Flash Messages are short announcements that appear on your Braille display for only a few seconds. These messages can include errors, status information, help balloons and other information. Use the options in this group to customize how JAWS displays Braille Flash Messages.

Controls.Label: &Enable Flash Messages
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box if you want JAWS to announce information by using Braille Flash Messages. Clear this check box to turn off Braille Flash Messages. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Flash Message &Timeout:
Controls.HelpMsg: Select the length of time (in milliseconds) that you want Braille Flash Messages to remain on the braille display. You can choose a value between zero and 30,000 milliseconds. One thousand milliseconds are equivalent to 1 second. Select the Manually Clear Only option if you want JAWS to keep the message on the display until you press a cursor routing button. The default interval is 5000 milliseconds.

Controls.Label: Enable Message &Prefixes
Controls.HelpMsg: If you select this check box and your braille display does not have any status cells, JAWS displays a special prefix before Braille Flash Messages to distinguish them from screen text. This prefix is a three-letter abbreviation that indicates the source of the message. This check box is selected by default. If your braille display has status cells, JAWS uses those to indicate that the text is a Braille Flash Message regardless of whether you select this check box. Clear this check box if you do not want to use this feature.

Controls.Label: &Verbosity Level
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine how much information JAWS displays using Braille Flash Messages. Beginner level displays the most information, while Advanced displays the least amount of information. Use the options in the Configure Verbosity Levels group to customize each level. The default verbosity level is Beginner.

Controls.Label: Configure Verbosity Levels
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this group to customize the Beginner, Intermediate, and Advanced verbosity settings for Braille Flash Messages. Each verbosity level contains default factory settings. Choose any of the three verbosity level buttons, and then toggle on or off any of these settings. This allows you to start with a basic configuration and modify it to your liking.

Controls.Label: &Beginner...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Beginner to open the Beginner Preferences dialog box. Use it to specify which items you want JAWS to display using Braille Flash Messages when the Beginner verbosity level is selected. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Intermediate...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Intermediate to open the Intermediate Preferences dialog box. Use it to specify which items you want JAWS to display using Braille Flash Messages when the Intermediate verbosity level is selected. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: A&dvanced...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Advanced to open the Advanced Preferences dialog box. Use it to specify which items you want JAWS to display using Braille Flash Messages when the Advanced verbosity level is selected. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure settings that determine how JAWS works with Web pages, HTML files, and PDF files. This includes items such as reading, navigating, and processing images, links, Web page elements, lists, and tables.
Use the options in this group to determine how graphics and images are announced when reading Web pages, HTML files, and PDF files.

Controls.Label: Include &Images
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this series of radio buttons to specify how you want JAWS to announce images within HTML documents. Select All Images to have JAWS speak any graphic it encounters, even ones without labels. Select Labeled Images to have JAWS speak only those graphics with alternate text specified within the HTML document. Select No Images to have JAWS ignore any image it finds, even if it is labeled. The default setting is Labeled Images.

Controls.Label: For an Image
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to configure what is announced when JAWS encounters graphics on a Web page. Using the Alt, Screen, and Title attributes of the HTML tag, you can set the search order in which JAWS announces this information.

Controls.Label: Title
Controls.HelpMsg: Select the Title radio button to have JAWS first look for and speak information provided by the HTML Title attribute. If this is not available, JAWS then looks for alt attribute information. Select the Alt Text radio button to have JAWS first look for and speak information provided by the HTML Alt attribute. If this is not available, JAWS then looks for Title attribute information. Alt Text is the default option. Select the Tooltip radio button to have JAWS look for the HTML OnMouseOver attribute, alt attribute, and then the title attribute. JAWS speaks the first information found. OnMouseOver attributes are often used to run script functions to display tooltips containing useful information. "OnMouseOver quoted text" is text provided through a function in the OnMouseOver attribute, in the form of: OnMouseOver="myfunction('information about graphic')". If more complex script code is referenced in the OnMouseOver attribute, the information is ignored. Select the Longest of Above radio button to have the longest string of information spoken for each graphic. Use the First Attribute Found in the Order List radio button together with the Order List edit box to create a customized search string to specify the order in which JAWS searches for information about graphics. When this radio button is selected, you can then edit the Order List edit box.

Controls.Label: The first attribute found in the order list
Order &List
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to enter a search string to define the attribute order used to search for and then speak information about graphics. A search string example is alt|src|title. Note: When typing a search string, separate attribute names with vertical bars and do not include spaces. This edit box is only available when you select The First Attribute Found in the Order List radio button.

Controls.Label: &Unlabeled Image Links
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to determine how JAWS announces image links when the HTML alt attribute or other identifying information is not available. JAWS can use the URL for the image, which is based on the HTML src attribute, or the URL for the link, which is based on the href attribute of the anchor tag. For example, select Speak Image's URL to use the HTML src attribute, which specifies the URL of an image, to announce information about an unlabeled image link. Select Speak Anchor's URL to use the HTML href attribute, which specifies the link address, to announce information about an unlabeled image link.  The default setting is Speak Image's URL.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to customize how Web pages, HTML files, and PDF files are read.

Controls.Label: Web Verbosity &Level
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this combo box to select a Virtual Cursor verbosity level. The verbosity level determines the amount of information spoken by JAWS when the Virtual Cursor is active. Each of the three levels is preset to give a different amount of detail and can be further configured to give only the information you want to hear. The default verbosity level is Medium, which creates an optimal user experience for most websites and documents.

Controls.Label: Configure Web Verbosity Levels
Controls.HelpMsg:
Use this group to customize the High, Medium, and Low verbosity settings for the Virtual Cursor. Each verbosity level contains default factory settings. Choose any of the three verbosity level buttons, and then toggle on or off any of these settings. This allows you to start with a basic configuration and modify it to your liking.
Note: If you turn off any region announcements, you will still hear the name and type of a region when using the R and SHIFT+R Navigation Quick Keys. In addition, if JAWS is configured to announce the start and end of forms, this information is not spoken if the form is not labelled and R or SHIFT+R will not move to any unlabelled form regions.

Controls.Label: &High...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose High to open the High Virtual Cursor Verbosity Preferences dialog box. Use it to adjust settings for the High Virtual Cursor verbosity level. High verbosity will cause JAWS to speak the most information about elements on the page or inside a document. By default, JAWS will speak everything at this level except the start and end of application and document regions. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Medium...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Medium to open the Medium Virtual Cursor Verbosity Preferences dialog box. Use it to adjust settings for the Medium Virtual Cursor verbosity level. Default settings for Medium verbosity are intended to provide the best user experience on most pages and documents. By default, JAWS will not indicate the start and end for flash objects or frames, and only the start and end of navigation and main regions is announced. Note that the name and type for all regions is still announced when using the R and SHIFT+R Navigation Quick Keys to move by region or the O and SHIFT+O Navigation Quick Keys to move by article. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: L&ow...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Low to open the Low Virtual Cursor Verbosity Preferences dialog box. Use it to adjust settings for the Low Virtual Cursor verbosity level. Low verbosity will cause JAWS to speak as little structural information as possible about the elements on a page or inside a document. By default, only the start and end of tables and grids is announced at this level. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Skip &Blank Lines While Navigating
Controls.HelpMsg:
When selected, JAWS and Fusion will skip over blank lines while navigating using the Virtual Cursor. This improves reading when navigating web pages, PDF documents, Help Files, and the JAWS Results Viewer without announcing all the blank lines. Clear this checkbox if you want to hear blank lines as you navigate text.
This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Document and Web Pages Automatically Read When Loaded
Controls.HelpMsg:
When selected, JAWS automatically begins reading web pages and PDF documents when loaded. Clear this check box if you do not want JAWS to automatically begin reading. Disabling this option is especially useful if you are using JAWS in conjunction with screen magnification software as the focus is not unexpectedly moved back to the top while you are using the mouse to navigate through the document. This checkbox is selected by default when only JAWS is running and is cleared by default when using Fusion or FSReader.
If you want to choose whether or not messages in Outlook are automatically read when opened, press INSERT+V while in Outlook to open Quick Settings, search for "Messages Automatically Read," and use SPACEBAR to select or clear this check box.

Controls.Label: Enable Fle&xible Web
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this setting to enable or disable the Flexible Web feature. You can access Flexible Web from Internet Explorer, Firefox, or Chrome by pressing INSERT+SPACEBAR, X. This check box is selected by default. This setting is only available in the JAWS default settings (CTRL+SHIFT+D).

Controls.Label: &Skip Past Repeated Text On New Pages
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS skips past repeated text often found on multiple pages within the same Web site. The Virtual PC cursor is placed at the beginning of new text on each page. This setting is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Expand Abbre&viations
Controls.HelpMsg: When Expand Abbreviations is selected, if a title attribute is present for an abbreviation, JAWS reads the title text instead of the on screen text. By default, JAWS reads the on screen text.

Controls.Label: Expand Acron&yms
Controls.HelpMsg: When Expand Acronyms is selected, if a title attribute is present for an acronym, JAWS reads the title text instead of the on screen text. By default, JAWS reads the on screen text.

Controls.Label: Speak Access Keys Within &Web Pages
Controls.HelpMsg: JAWS announces access keys assigned to HTML elements using the HTML Accesskey attribute. Access keys let you move directly to an item such as a link or form control. Clear this check box if you do not want JAWS to announce access keys in web pages. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Custom &Placemarker Page Summary
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to determine how PlaceMarkers are announced for Web pages, HTML files, and PDF files. When you open a virtual document (such as an HTML page), the PlaceMarker Page Summary feature automatically lists each PlaceMarker on the page, along with its associated text.  (Note that when you use Settings Center to choose a custom PlaceMarker page summary setting, it will apply to ALL HTML pages.)  Select Speak PlaceMarkers on Page Load to hear the name of each PlaceMarker and its associated text. Select List PlaceMarkers in Results Viewer on Page Load to have PlaceMarker information for the page appear in the Results Viewer. Select Do Nothing if you do not want to hear the PlaceMarker summary. The default setting is Do Nothing.

Controls.Label: List Placemarkers in Results Viewer On Page Load

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to define how JAWS navigates or moves through blocks and lines of text when reading Web pages, HTML files, and PDF files.

Controls.Label: Smart Na&vigation Mode
Controls.HelpMsg:
Smart Navigation offers a more efficient way to navigate in web-based applications, tables, and forms. When set to "Controls," most controls are treated as single units when navigating by character or word, like moving through a menu bar with RIGHT and LEFT ARROW. When set to "Controls and Tables," controls are treated as single units when navigating by character or word, while inside a table, the ARROW keys move between cells. When set to Tables, the ARROW keys move between cells while focused in a table, while outside of a table, navigating by character and word works as it always has. In either case, you can always get to traditional navigation such as character or word, by pressing the Say Character, Say Word, or Say Line commands twice quickly so you can explore the text of the control in more traditional ways. To return to Smart Navigation, just press DOWN ARROW, ESC, or TAB. When Smart Navigation is active, the Document Presentation Mode setting is changed to Screen Layout, which offers a much more natural movement through pages the way they appear on screen.
Smart Navigation is off by default.
To temporarily toggle this setting between Off and Controls and Tables, use insert+x. This also modifies the Document Presentation Mode setting appropriately. The toggle is always temporary, meaning it only stays in effect until you do something that moves focus away from your current browser window such as ALT+TAB.

Controls.Label: &Document Presentation Mode
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to change how HTML, PDF, and other virtual documents are structured in the virtual buffer.

Controls.Label: Select Layout
Controls.HelpMsg: Use these radio buttons to determine how items are arranged in the Virtual Buffer. Select Simple Layout to have links, form fields, buttons, and other page controls display on a separate line. This is the default setting if Smart Navigation is not enabled. Select Screen Layout to have pages rendered in the virtual buffer in a way that is similar to what a sighted user sees on the screen. If page controls visually appear on the same line, then they will appear on the same line in the virtual buffer. In addition, all items in a single table row display on the same line. Table cells are separated by a vertical bar. Screen Layout is used when Smart Navigation is set to Controls or Controls and Tables and cannot be changed while Smart Navigation is active.

Controls.Label: Ma&ximum Line Length
Controls.HelpMsg: This setting determines how long a single line will be when viewing an HTML page in Document Presentation Mode. This can help when reading lengthy tables because all content from each table row can fit on a single line. The increased line length stops JAWS from rendering rows across multiple lines. When you exit Document Presentation Mode, JAWS will render the page using the normal maximum line length. The default line length in Document Presentation Mode is 400 characters, which is enough to fit most table rows on one line. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Text &Block Length
Controls.HelpMsg: When you press INSERT+ENTER for Move To Next Non-Link Text, JAWS looks for a block of text that is not part of a link, and whose length is equal to or greater than the number of characters specified in this edit box. The default value is 25. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: &Lines Per Page
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this setting to determine how many lines the Virtual PC Cursor moves when you press PAGE UP or PAGE DOWN. You may want to increase this amount if working with pages that have a large number of links. The default value is 24. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: &Maximum Line Length
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this setting to determine how many characters the Virtual PC Cursor treats as one line of text. The default value is 150. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: &Screen Tracks Virtual Cursor
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, the screen updates while reading with the Virtual PC cursor. This assures that the text you are currently reading is displayed on the screen at the same time. When not selected, the Virtual PC cursor can still access all information in a Web page, but the on screen display does not track as the Virtual PC cursor moves through the document. This setting is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Wrap &Navigation
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, Navigation Quick Key commands wrap after reaching the beginning or end of an HTML document. When cleared, JAWS speaks a message informing you that no more matches are found, such as no more tables. This item is selected by default.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine how Web links are announced.

Controls.Label: &Filter Consecutive Duplicate Links
Controls.HelpMsg: This option controls whether consecutive links that point to the same location, one graphical and one text, are filtered. When selected, only the text link is announced. This check box is selected by default in Internet Explorer and cleared by default in Chrome and Firefox.

Controls.Label: Say Lin&k Type
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS announces the type of links encountered when navigating through HTML documents. Such link types include Send Mail links or FTP links. This setting is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Identify ""Same &Page"" Links
Controls.HelpMsg: If this check box is selected, JAWS announces when links point to other locations on the same page by stating "same page link." This setting is checked by default.

Controls.Label: For a Text Link
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine what information is spoken when a text-based link is encountered.

Controls.Label: &Speak
Controls.HelpMsg: Select the Title radio button to hear the Title text, if it is available, for a text-based link. This text does not display on the screen. Select Screen Text to hear JAWS read the on screen text for the link. This is the default setting. Select Tooltip to have JAWS first look for "OnMouseOver quoted text" and then speak that information. "OnMouseOver" attributes are often used to run script functions to display tooltips containing useful information. If no OnMouseOver quoted text is found, JAWS speaks the on screen text for the link. "OnMouseOver quoted text" is text provided through a function in the "OnMouseOver" HTML attribute, in the form of: OnMouseOver="myfunction('information about link')". If more complex script code is referenced in the "OnMouseOver" attribute, the information is ignored. Select Longest of Above to have JAWS speak the longest string of information for the link. Use The First Attribute Found in the Order List option and the Order List edit box to define and use a search string.

Controls.Label: The first attribute found in the order list
Order &List
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to specify the order in which JAWS searches for information about text links. JAWS speaks the first string of  information found. Enter a search string containing the names of HTML attributes used with  the "A" (Anchor) element. Use the value "screentext" for on screen text. Separate the attribute names with vertical bars. Do not include spaces. For example,  "title|onmouseover|href" or "title|screentext|href."

Controls.Label: Include Ima&ge Links
Controls.HelpMsg: Graphics are often used as links. Use the options in this subgroup to determine which graphical links are announced. Labeled graphics are those where a text description has been assigned to the graphic. By default, JAWS announces all graphical links.

Controls.Label: Identify Image &Map Links
Controls.HelpMsg: Sections of images are often mapped out by coordinates and used as links. Use this series of radio buttons to determine which image map links are announced. Setting JAWS to announce only those links with alternate tags prevents reading of links with confusing or no text, but may also prevent access to important links on the page. The default setting is announce All Image Map Links.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure how tables in web pages, HTML files, and PDF files are announced.

Controls.Label: Indicate ColSpan for &Braille
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have JAWS insert one vertical bar per column span between table cells. This can help when reading HTML tables with cells that span multiple columns. For example, if a table cell spans two columns, the contents of that cell will be followed by two vertical bars on the braille display. This provides a better representation of the visual layout of HTML tables. This check box is selected by default. Note that this check box is only applicable when Documentation Presentation Mode is set to Screen Layout. This option is found in the Navigation group.

Controls.Label: &Table Presentation Information
Controls.HelpMsg: JAWS can be set to detect only data tables, or to detect all tables; this includes tables used to format the layout of the page. The nesting level of each table is also announced. Tables are often used to provide page layout formatting, so setting this option to All Tables can provide a lot of information on some pages. The default setting is For Data Tables Only.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine how headings and frames are announced when reading Web pages, HTML files, and PDF files.

Controls.Label: Heading &Navigation using 1-6
Controls.HelpMsg:
Use the radio buttons in this group to determine what happens during heading navigation when using the numbers row to navigate to headings at a given level.
Restrict to Section restricts navigation to finding headings with an equal or lower precedence. For example, searching for a heading at level 3 (h3) when the next heading is an h2 will stop since the h2 indicates the start of a new section whose level has a higher precedence than the heading you are searching for.
Speak Ancestor Headings when Jumping to a New Section will find the next heading with the given level, but if it is under a different higher precedence heading, the immediately higher precedence heading will be read so you know that the new heading belongs to a different section.
If Play Sound when Jumping to a New Section is selected, heading navigation will find the next heading with the given level, but if it is under a different higher precedence heading, a sound plays to indicate that the heading belongs to a different section.
By default, you can move through heading levels using the numbers row without restriction and JAWS speaks the heading level for the new section when it changes.

Controls.Label: Speak Ancestor Headings when Jumping to a New Section
Play Sound when Jumping to a New Section
Indicate &Headings
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to specify if headings are not announced, announced as headings only, announced with the heading level indicated, announced using a WAV file sound instead of speech, or announced using the Headings voice. By default, headings are announced with the level indicated. When used properly, headings indicate the relationship of each section of the page to the page as a whole.

Controls.Label: Ignore &Inline Frames
Controls.HelpMsg: Inline frames are often used to display advertisements. However, some Web pages do use inline frames for important information. By default, JAWS reads the content of inline frames. Select Ignore Inline Frames if you do not want to hear the information within frames.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure various elements such as Flash processing, Form field announcement, button announcement, and page refreshes for Web pages, HTML files, and PDF files.

Controls.Label: Ignore &Flash On Web Pages
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to turn off all processing of Flash on Web pages.  This has the same effect as setting the ActiveX Refresh Filter option to Suppress All Refreshes. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: For a Form Field &Prompt Speak
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to identify prompts or labels for form fields. Select any of the following  HTML attributes: Label Tag, Title, or Alt Text. You can also choose to have the longest of these three attributes announced, or a combination of label and title if these attributes are different, or a combination of labels and alt text if these attributes are different. The default setting is Label Tag.

Controls.Label: Both Label and Title if different
Both Label and Alt if different
Page &Refresh Filter
Controls.HelpMsg: Web pages are sometimes set to automatically refresh and update information. This can cause JAWS to start reading over from the beginning of the page, and make it very difficult to use. To control how frequently the page content refreshes, use the Page Refresh Filter command. Select Refresh As Needed to refresh the page based on how often components on the page automatically update. This is the default setting. Select Refresh Every 60 Seconds to refresh the page at 60-second intervals. Select Suppress All Refreshes to never refresh the current page as long as it has focus. Note: If you select Suppress All Refreshes, certain pages may perform or read poorly. It is recommended that you only suppress all refreshes for pages that are difficult to use. To do this, open the page in your web browser and use the Personalized Web Settings feature.

Controls.Label: &Link Activation
Controls.HelpMsg:
This option affects how links are activated when you press the ENTER key in a virtual document.
When this option is set to "Enter simulates mouse click," pressing the ENTER key on a link actually simulates a left mouse click on the link. This is how JAWS behaved prior to JAWS 15.
When this option is set to "Enter sends Enter key," pressing the ENTER key on a link instead causes the ENTER key to be passed on to the system. You may want to choose this setting if pressing ENTER does not activate a Web element unless you first press INSERT+3 to enable the Pass Key Through feature.
The default setting is "Enter simulates mouse click."

Controls.Label: For a &Button
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to identify buttons used in forms. Select any of the following  HTML attributes: Title, Screen Text, Alt Text, or Value. You can also choose to have the longest of these attributes announced, or you can create a customized search string, using the Order List edit box, to specify the order in which JAWS searches for information about buttons. The default setting is Screen Text.

Controls.Label: Speak
Controls.HelpMsg: Select the type of HTML attribute to announce for buttons in a form. HTML attributes include Title, Screen Text, Alt Text, or Value. Select Longest of Above to have the longest of these attributes spoken. Select The First Attribute Found in the Order List radio button to create a customized search string, along with the Order List edit box, to specify the order in which JAWS searches for information about buttons. The default setting is Screen Text.

Controls.Label: The first attribute found in the order list
Order List
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to enter a search string to define the attribute order used to search for and then speak information about buttons. A search string example is alt|src|title. Note: When typing a search string, separate attribute names with vertical bars and do not include spaces. This edit box is only available when you select The First Attribute Found in the Order List radio button.

Controls.Label: Indicate Element &Attribute
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have JAWS indicate the attribute of HTML elements of Web pages. The attributes that JAWS announces are determined by the Attributes page in Speech and Sounds Schemes. Clearing this check box suppresses announcements by JAWS of all the attributes that have been enabled using Speech and Sounds Schemes. To suppress or change such announcements, the recommended method is to open the Attributes page of Speech and Sounds Schemes and change the behavior for the desired attributes. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Allow &Web Application Reserved Keystrokes
Controls.HelpMsg: Certain interactive Web sites may offer keyboard shortcuts to perform some common tasks. For example, on the Facebook Web site you can press P to post a status, L to like a story, C to comment on a story, or J and K to scroll between News Feed stories. However, these keystrokes also conflict with JAWS Navigation Quick Keys. When this check box is selected, any JAWS keystrokes that are also defined as keystrokes by a Web site will perform the site specific task instead of the JAWS command. For this to work correctly, the page must also include a line of code that tells JAWS what keystrokes are defined by the web site. If this information is not available, all JAWS commands will continue to work as expected. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to set the verbosity level. Verbosity determines the amount of information spoken by JAWS. Each verbosity level is preset to give a different amount of detail. Each level can be further customized to give only the information you want to hear. The default selection is Beginner, which gives the most detailed information.

Controls.Label: &Verbosity Level
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to select a verbosity level. Verbosity determines the amount of information spoken by JAWS. Each of the three levels is preset to give a different amount of detail, depending on your experience level. Each verbosity level can be further customized to give only the information you want to hear. The default selection is Beginner, which gives the most detailed information.

Controls.Label: Configure Verbosity Levels
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this group to customize the Beginner, Intermediate, and Advanced verbosity settings. Each verbosity level contains default factory settings. Choose any of the three verbosity level buttons, and then toggle on or off any of these settings. This allows you to start with a basic configuration and modify it to your liking.

Controls.Label: &Beginner...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Beginner to open the Beginner Preferences dialog box. Use it to adjust settings for the Beginner verbosity level. By default, Beginner verbosity speaks the most detailed information. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Intermediate...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Intermediate to open the Intermediate Preferences dialog box. Use it to adjust settings for the Intermediate verbosity level. By default, Intermediate verbosity speaks a medium amount of information. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: A&dvanced...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Advanced to open the Advanced Preferences dialog box. Use it to adjust settings for the Advanced Verbosity level. By default, Advanced verbosity speaks a limited amount of information. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Enable Speech History
Controls.HelpMsg: If this check box is selected, JAWS will retain a history of the last 50 items spoken by the speech synthesizer in order to review in the event you need to listen to it again or read it in detail. To view the history, press INSERT+SPACEBAR, followed by H. This will place the history in a window where you can navigate and read it in detail. If you would like to clear the current content of the history, you can do so by pressing INSERT+SPACEBAR, followed by SHIFT+H. This setting is enabled by default.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure basic braille operation. These options include items such as braille translation, braille cursor behavior, and panning modes.

Controls.Label: Translation
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure braille translation settings.

Controls.Label: Lan&guage
Controls.HelpMsg: Select a Braille language from the list. By default, the language is set to English-United States.

Controls.Label: Ou&tput
Controls.HelpMsg: Select a Braille output mode from the list. The first option is always Computer Braille. The other available options depend on the currently selected language. The default output mode is Computer Braille.

Controls.Label: &Input
Controls.HelpMsg: Select a Braille input mode from the list. The first option is always Computer Braille. The other available options depends on the currently selected output mode. The default input mode is Computer Braille. This setting is not available if the selected output mode is Computer Braille, or the selected output mode does not support input.

Controls.Label: Show current word in Comput&er Braille
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have the word at the current cursor position display in Computer Braille. Clear this check box to display the word in Contracted Braille. This check box is available only when the output mode is Grade 1 or Grade 2 and the input mode is Computer Braille. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Show F&ont Attribute Marks
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to show Braille indicators when encountering text using specific attributes such as bold, underline, or italics. This check box is cleared by default and is only available if the output mode is Grade 1 or Grade 2.

Controls.Label: Language Pro&files...
Controls.HelpMsg:
For multi-lingual users, choose this option to open the Language Profiles dialog box where you can configure settings for individual braille profiles. A braille profile consists of a translator mode and associated braille tables for input and output in a specific language. Use this dialog box to set the primary Braille profile as well as select preferred profiles. You can then use the CTRL+SHIFT+WINDOWS+L keystroke, or DOTS 2-3-4-5-7 CHORD on a Focus braille display, to quickly switch between preferred profiles if you need to read or type text in different languages.
Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Brai&lle Mode
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this option to control the format of the information sent to the braille display. When Line mode is selected, JAWS sends the line of text at the current cursor position to the braille display. When Structured mode is selected, JAWS sends information to the display that is relevant to the current cursor position. The information sent includes things such as control type, dialog name, or number of items in a list. When Speech Output mode is selected, JAWS sends the same text to the display that it sends to the synthesizer. The default setting for this option is Structured.

Controls.Label: Panning
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to define a Panning mode when using your braille display.

Controls.Label: Use&r Pan Mode
Controls.HelpMsg: Panning with your braille display generally moves the display to the left or right by the length of the display. You do this by pressing a panning key on the braille display. Select Best Fit to ensure that words are not cut off when panning. Select Fixed Increment to ensure the braille display always pans the exact number of cells available on the display. Select Maximize Text to show the maximum amount of text that can fit on the braille display. Select Automatic to allow JAWS to choose the best method for showing text on the braille display. The default selection is Automatic.

Controls.Label: &Pan Text by Paragraph
Controls.HelpMsg:
This setting determines how much text is shown on the Braille display and how it is navigated when panning through a document such as a web page or Word document.
When this check box is selected, panning shows the entire paragraph on the display, only showing a blank space if a word does not fit or the paragraph ends. When cleared, panning moves by what JAWS determines to be a line, which means that you could have large blank spaces after the text as there is nothing more on the current line.
This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: Auto Pan &Mode
Controls.HelpMsg: This setting determines how the content of the braille display is updated when the active cursor moves outside the area currently displayed. Select Off to turn off automatic panning. If you select Match User Panning, JAWS pans the braille display using the same method specified in the User Pan list. Select Automatic to allow JAWS to choose the best method for showing text on your braille display. The default selection is Automatic.

Controls.Label: Auto Advance Maximum Inter&val
Controls.HelpMsg: Select the maximum length of time (in milliseconds) that you want JAWS to wait before panning the braille display while you are reading in Auto Advance mode. You can choose any value between 500 to 20,000 milliseconds. 1,000 milliseconds are equivalent to 1 second. The default interval is 5000 milliseconds.

Controls.Label: Braille Presentation and Panning
Controls.HelpMsg: Select an item to determine the braille cursor's panning behavior. You can apply this as the JAWS default or only to specific applications. JAWS uses the Off Screen Model (OSM) and the Document Object Model (DOM) methods to determine the extent of braille cursor movement and control when panning. The advantage of OSM is that the braille cursor can freely navigate the computer screen; however, it does not provide enough detailed information for some applications. The advantage of the DOM is that it provides accurate details, but limits braille cursor navigation to the visible part of the current document. The default setting is Use DOM Except in Edit Controls.

Controls.Label: Reverse &Panning Buttons
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to switch the direction of left and right panning buttons on a braille display. This means that when you press a left Navrow or panning button, panning advances to the right. Likewise, when you press a right Navrow or panning button, panning advances to the left. Clear this check box to restore normal panning operation. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: A&ctive cursor follows Braille display
Controls.HelpMsg: If selected, the braille display and the active cursor are linked together, so that when you pan the braille display, the active cursor also moves. However, you cannot pan the braille display where the active cursor cannot move. For example, with the PC cursor active, you cannot read down to the status line of a window. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: &Braille cursor follows Active cursor
Controls.HelpMsg: If selected, the braille display tracks along as you move the active cursor, but is not limited to where the active cursor can move. For example, when moving through a dialog, the braille display moves to each control as you press TAB. In Structured mode, the braille display always follows the active cursor, even if you do not select this check box. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Display text in &8 Dot Braille Mode
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have text displayed in 8 Dot braille. In 8 Dot Braille mode, JAWS uses DOTS 7 and 8 on the braille display to indicate capitalization and special symbols in computer braille. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Enable Braille &Sleep Mode
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this option to disable the braille driver for a specific application. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: Enable &Word Wrap
Controls.HelpMsg: If you select this check box, JAWS does not split a word that is too large to be shown on the braille display. When you pan to the next increment, you can read the word in its entirety. If you clear this check box, JAWS displays as much of the word as possible, but a portion may be cut off. JAWS shows the remainder of the word when you pan to the next increment. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Auto &Detect Braille Display using Bluetooth
Controls.HelpMsg: When on, JAWS detects and begins sending information to Bluetooth displays as they come in range without the need to restart JAWS. The default setting is off, which means that Bluetooth displays will only be detected when JAWS first starts.

HelpMsg: Structured Mode provides descriptive information about the dialog box or control that currently has focus. These options allow you to configure how the structured line is shown on your braille display.

Controls.Label: Include Optional Components
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this group of options to determine what is included in the structured line.

Controls.Label: &Type
Controls.HelpMsg: Select an option to determine where control type information will be included in the structured line. Off, does not display control type information. On, includes it in the main cells of the display with the rest of the structured data. On (In Status Cells), displays it in the status cells of the braille display. The default setting is On (In Status Cells).

Controls.Label: Show &Level and Position
Controls.HelpMsg:
Select this check box to include the tree view level, position of a list item, or the position of a radio button in the structured representation of the
focused control. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Show &Hotkey
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to include the hotkey, or access key, of a control in the structured representation of the focused control. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Show &Other Hints
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to include context help or HTML attributes (if applicable) of a control in the structured representation of the focused control. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Show &Dialog Title
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to include the title of the dialog box in the structured representation of the focused control. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Show Dialog D&escriptive Text
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to include dialog box descriptive text in the structured representation of the focused control. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Show &Control Group Info
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to include the group box name of the current item in the structured representation of the focused control. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Align to &Structured Segment
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to align to the most appropriate Structured Mode segment when a control gains focus. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Reverse Order of Structured Data
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to reverse the order of the structured data to show the focused control's info first, followed by its grouping information, and then the dialog box information. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Ad&vanced...
Controls.HelpMsg: Activate this button to open the Control Type Options dialog box where you can modify the structured mode representation of individual control types.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to adjust the location of the status cells and vary the firmness of braille dots on displays that support these features. See your display's documentation for more information.

Controls.Label: &Placement of Status cells
Controls.HelpMsg: Use these radio buttons to determine if the informational Status Cells are located on the left or right end of the display, or choose to not display them at all. Left is the default setting.

Controls.Label: &Dot Firmness
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this slider to specify the firmness of braille dots on the Focus or PAC Mate Portable Braille display. There are five levels of firmness.

Controls.Label: Grade 2 Translator
Controls.HelpMsg: Select the translator you wish to use to convert text into Grade 2 Braille.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine how JAWS reads text. This includes how to announce capitalization, identify the beginning and end of tables, announce list items, numbers, and dates, indicate new lines, and more.
Use the options in this group to control how JAWS processes and announces numeric and date formats.

Controls.Label: Numeric Da&te Processing
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this list to determine how to announce dates written in numeric formats. Select No Translation to read numeric dates as numbers. This is the default. Select Some Translation to have numeric dates, for example, 01-01-10, spoken as month, day, and year using slashes or dashes for separation. Select Extended Translation to have numeric dates spoken only as month and day and separated by slashes or dashes. Note that numeric fractions, such as 1/3, are read as dates.

Controls.Label: Use System &Locale For Date Format Information
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS will use the current user or system locale to obtain information on the format of dates. Clear this check box to have JAWS obtain date format information using either the document or speech synthesizer language. This check box is used in conjunction with the Numeric Date Processing combo box and is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Number Processing
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this list to determine how numbers are read. Select Controlled by Synthesizer to let the synthesizer decide how numbers are read. This is the default. Select Controlled by JAWS to have JAWS send numbers to the synthesizer the way they should be read. Use this setting if the synthesizer currently in use is not speaking numbers correctly when using Controlled by Synthesizer. Select Single Digits to read numbers as individual digits. For example, "123" is read as "one two three." Select Pairs to read numbers in pairs. For example, "1050" is read as "ten fifty." For numbers with an odd number of digits, JAWS reads the first digit as a single number and pairs the rest. For example, "123" is read as "one twenty three." Select Full Numbers to always read numbers as whole numbers. For example, "123" is read as "one hundred twenty three."

Controls.Label: Enable C&urrency Recognition
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS will recognize currency strings such as '$100' and convert them to text like 'one hundred U.S. dollars'. Clear this check box to disable recognition of currency strings. This check box is available when the Number Processing combo box is set to “Controlled by JAWS” and is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Speak &Single Digits
Controls.HelpMsg: The options in this group are used together with the Number Processing combo box to determine how JAWS reads a number string.

Controls.Label: &If Number Contains
Controls.HelpMsg: Select a threshold value so that number strings are read as individual digits. This is useful when reading long number strings such as telephone numbers, serial numbers, and part numbers. This rule applies under the following conditions: the number string is not preceded by or followed by an alpha character, and it does not contain a dash, colon, decimal, or slash to separate the digits similar to telephone, time, or date formatting. To override the dash exception of this rule, select the If Number Contains Dashes check box. Other combo box values are Six or More Digits, Seven or More Digits, Eight or More Digits, and Controlled by Synthesizer, which allows the current synthesizer to determine how numbers are read. Use this item in conjunction with the Number Processing combo box. When reading a number string, JAWS first considers the value for the Number Processing combo box, and then the If Number Contains combo box.

Controls.Label: If Number &contains Dashes
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, numbers that contain dashes without spaces are read as individual digits. Telephone number formatting, where a dash is preceded by and followed by a digit, is an example of this type of number string. This check box is used in conjunction with the Number Processing combo box. This means that JAWS processes numbers based on the current selection in the Number Processing combo box.  This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Speak &Dollars
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, numbers preceded by a dollar sign are read using the dollars and cents format. For example, $9.95 is read as nine dollars and ninety five cents. To read monetary values less than a dollar, a zero is required to represent dollars. For example, $0.02 is read as two cents. This check box is cleared by default.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure settings for spelling and grammatical error detection.

Controls.Label: Detect &Spelling While Navigating
Controls.HelpMsg:
Use this combo box to choose how spelling errors are indicated while reading a document.
Select "Off" if you do not want JAWS to indicate spelling errors.
Select "Play Sound" to hear a buzzer when you navigate into a misspelled word.
Select "Say misspelled" to have JAWS say "misspelled" when you navigate into an error.
The default setting is "Say Misspelled."

Controls.Label: De&tect Spelling While Typing
Controls.HelpMsg:
This check box allows you to choose how spelling errors are indicated while typing. When cleared, no spelling errors will be indicated. When selected, a sound will be played as soon as the application detects that you have either mistyped or corrected a word.
This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Speak Spelling Error &Count
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this Check box to hear the number of spelling errors prior to hearing the text of the line when reading by line. This check box is cleared by default and is not available if Detect Spelling While Navigating is off.

Controls.Label: &Grammar and Advanced Proofing
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS speaks a message to indicate when you navigate into or out of grammatical or advanced proofing errors. This check box is selected by default for all applications, enabling JAWS to announce grammatical errors detected in web-based editors like Google Docs. This check box is only cleared by default in Microsoft Word and Outlook as the grammar and proofing detection features in Word are much stricter than in most online editors and can lead to more verbose speech.

Controls.Label: Speak Grammar/Pr&oofing Error Count
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to hear the number of grammatical or proofing errors prior to hearing the text of the line when reading by line. This check box is cleared by default and is not available if grammar and advanced proofing detection is off.

Controls.Label: A&pply options during SayAll
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have JAWS indicate spelling and grammar errors when reading a document using Say All (INSERT+DOWN ARROW). This check box is cleared by default and is not available if both spelling and grammar detection are off.

Controls.Label: Comm&ent Announcement
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this combo box to choose how JAWS alerts you when encountering text with comments in web-based editors like Google Docs. Available choices are Off, Speak, or Play Sound. By default, JAWS speaks a message when navigating into or out of commented text.

Controls.Label: &Inserted Text Announcement
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS speaks a message to indicate when you navigate into or out of inserted text in web-based editors like Google Docs. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Deleted Text Announcement
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS speaks a message to indicate when you navigate into or out of deleted text in web-based editors like Google Docs. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Marked Text Announcement
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS speaks a message to indicate when you navigate into or out of text inside a mark element in web-based editors like Google Docs. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Suggested Text Announcement
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS speaks a message to indicate when you navigate into or out of suggested text in web-based editors like Google Docs. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Braille
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to choose whether or not spelling and grammar errors are indicated in Braille.

Controls.Label: &Underline Spelling Errors
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to mark spelling errors in Braille using dots 7 and 8. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: U&nderline Grammatical and advanced proofing errors
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to mark grammatical and proofing errors in Braille using dots 7 and 8. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: &Filter Control Characters such as Page Breaks
Controls.HelpMsg: Clear this check box to allow Braille output for various control characters such as page breaks. Depending on the application you are using, different control characters could be displayed. These will be presented for both Computer Braille or Contracted Braille output. This check box is selected by default.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure settings for language detection.

Controls.Label: &Detect Language
Controls.HelpMsg:
This group of radio buttons allows you to configure automatic language detection. This feature works with synthesizers, such as Eloquence or Vocalizer Expressive, that support multiple languages. For Vocalizer Expressive, you must install voices for a particular language for this detection to work properly.
Select "Based On Markup of document and web page" to have JAWS detect changes in languages within documents which support language tags. JAWS then reads using the appropriate synthesizer voice for the specified language. For example, if JAWS finds Spanish tags on a Web page, that text is spoken using a Spanish voice.
Select "Based On Text (Vocalizer Expressive only)" to have JAWS detect the language based on the types of text characters used in the document and read using the appropriate Vocalizer Expressive voice. For example, if JAWS detects Arabic characters, JAWS will switch to an Arabic voice for reading, if available.
Select "Based on AI predictions" to have JAWS use an AI algorithm that runs on your computer to determine the language of a piece of text before speaking it. JAWS then switches to the appropriate voice for that language, if available.
Select "Off" if you do not want JAWS to change the synthesizer voice when reading text written in another language.

Controls.Label: Based On Markup of document and web page
When Detect Language Based On &Text
Controls.HelpMsg:
This group of radio buttons lets you determine how numbers are spoken when language detection is set to "Based On Text." You can choose to have numbers spoken using the primary voice, or you can have numbers read using a voice that matches the language context of the numbers.
The default is to read numbers using the primary voice.

Controls.Label: Numbers are spoken with primary voice
Numbers are spoken based on language context
&Enhanced right-to-left (RTL) support
Controls.HelpMsg:
Select this check box to make sure that right-to-left text is spoken in the correct order by the synthesizer.
This check box is cleared by default for all languages except Arabic and Hebrew.
