Controls.Label: Generali&ze Dialect
Controls.HelpMsg:
This check box determines if JAWS switches to a different language to account for dialects within the same base language. For example, if this feature is selected, and JAWS is reading, in English, a Web page that supports U.S. English, U.K. English, and Australian English, JAWS will not switch between languages since the base language is English. However, if JAWS encounters another language, such as German or French, it will switch to that language.
This check box is selected by default and is only available when language detection is set to "Based On Markup of document and web page."

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to control overall speech behavior.

Controls.Label: Filter Repeated C&haracters
Controls.HelpMsg:
This list allows you to determine how many times a character is spoken when an uninterrupted series of repeating characters is encountered. You can choose from the following options: Three, Four, Five, Six, All, or count. Note that when set to three, four, five, six, or all, spaces are not reported. However, spaces are reported when set to count. This is useful in editors where knowing the number of spaces matters, such as when programming.
The default is to announce the first three repeated characters.

Controls.Label: Indicate Capitalizati&on
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this list to specify when to announce capitalization. The default setting is "Read By Char, Spell," which indicates capital letters only when reading by character and when spelling. Select "No Indication" if you do not want JAWS to indicate capital letters. Select "Read By Word, Char, Spell" if you want JAWS to indicate capital letters when reading by word or character, and when spelling. Select "Read By Line, Word, Char, Spell" if you want JAWS to indicate capital letters when reading by line, word, or character, and when spelling.

Controls.Label: &List Item
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this list to determine how JAWS describes list box items. Select Say None to silence reading of list box descriptions. When you select Say Selected, JAWS only tells you when list box items are selected. When you select the Say Not Selected item, JAWS only tells you when list box items are not selected. This is the default setting. If you select Say Both, JAWS tells you when list box items are selected, and when they are not selected.

Controls.Label: &Spell Alphanumeric Data
Controls.HelpMsg: Select one of the following to determine how JAWS reads alphanumeric information: Off, which is the default setting, reads the text as it appears. For example, the license plate number 123RON is read as one hundred twenty-three Ron. The Spell option spells alphanumeric data. For example, 123RON is read as 1 2 3 R O N. Spell Phonetically uses the phonetic alphabet to spell alphanumeric data. For example, JAWS reads 123RON as 1 2 3 Romeo Oscar November.

Controls.Label: Indicate Newlines When
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to control how JAWS indicates a new line when you are typing or reading text.

Controls.Label: Editor Wraps Text While Typin&g
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box if you want JAWS to indicate that you have moved to a new line when reading by word or character. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: User &Navigates Left Or Right Across a Line Break
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to indicate new lines when reading by word or character. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: User Rea&ds Text Containing Newline Characters
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have JAWS indicate a new line of text when it encounters a newline character. In computing, a newline character can be a line feed, carriage return, end-of-line, or line break.    This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: During Sa&y All
Controls.HelpMsg: Select to indicate movement to a new line when reading by Say All.  This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: Phonetic Announcement
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to control JAWS phonetic announcement of letters when reading text.

Controls.Label: S&pell Phonetically Always
Controls.HelpMsg: When this check box is cleared, using the commands to spell the current word or line (INSERT+NUM PAD 5 or INSERT+UP ARROW twice quickly) causes JAWS to speak each character as expected. When selected, you will always get phonetic representation for each character in the word or line as they are spelled. For example, when pressing INSERT+NUM PAD 5 twice quickly to spell "JAWS," the word would be read as Juliet Alpha Whiskey Sierra. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: When p&ausing after character navigation, speak character phonetically
Controls.HelpMsg:
While navigating text by character, it may be helpful to hear the phonetic representation for a particular letter. When this option is enabled, pausing on a letter for a brief period of time will allow JAWS to speak it phonetically.
JAWS also offers a manual option to speak phonetics continuously as you navigate by character. Pressing the Say Character keystroke twice quickly toggles this feature on and off. If you are using the manual option for all letters, the pause announcement will not occur.
By default, phonetic announcements will happen if you pause for one and a half seconds when navigating by character.

Controls.Label: Announce L&ive Region Updates
Controls.HelpMsg:
This option controls the announcement of live region updates on web pages and applications that support them. When this check box is cleared, no live region updates will be spoken.
This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: S&mart Word Reading
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have JAWS read the entire text unit, such as a compound word, telephone number, date, time, or math equation, when using the Say Word command.  Note: Cursor movement is controlled by the application. So, if Microsoft Word's cursor normally navigates the entire text unit as one word or number, then the text is read in the same way. Likewise, if an application, such as WordPad, navigates through each component of the text unit, then JAWS will read it the same way.  This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Mi&xed case processing
Controls.HelpMsg: If checked, words are pronounced based on capitalization as well as spacing. This makes JAWS better pronounce words that contain embedded capital letters. For example, Say All is pronounced as if it were two separate words. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Use Dictionary
Controls.HelpMsg: If this check box is selected, words, phrases, abbreviations, or symbols are processed through a global or application specific dictionary to determine proper pronunciation. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Detect &Keyboard Language
Controls.HelpMsg:
When this check box is selected, JAWS uses the appropriate language voice that matches the currently active language keyboard. For example, if you switch the input language to Spanish, JAWS will automatically switch to a Spanish voice, if available, as you type.
Clear this check box if you want JAWS to continue using the current language voice even if you switch keyboard input to a different language.
This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: &Enhanced Edit Support
Controls.HelpMsg: If you select this check box, JAWS provides enhanced support for edit and rich edit areas. This feature allows for increased accuracy while reading text in these areas. In addition, enhanced edit support allows JAWS to recognize an extended selection of text attributes and better detect languages automatically. However, you may experience reduced responsiveness while using certain programs. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Say Item State &First
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have the selected state of an item in a list box spoken before the name of the item is spoken. For example, JAWS says, "Not Selected, My Documents," instead of, "My Documents, Not Selected."  This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Say &Window Type First
Controls.HelpMsg: If selected, the window type is spoken before the window title or text. For example, JAWS would say, "Dialog Find," instead of, "Find Dialog." This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: Say Window State Fi&rst
Controls.HelpMsg: If selected, the window state is spoken before the window title or text. For example, JAWS would say, "Not Checked Match Case check box," instead of, "Match Case check box Not Checked." This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: Say Indented &Characters
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this option to determine if JAWS announces the distance of indented text from the left or right margin.  To customize how JAWS indicates indentation, use Speech and Sound Schemes.  This check box is cleared by default.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine how JAWS reacts to cursors and carets.

Controls.Label: &Notify When Mouse Cursor Changes Shape
Controls.HelpMsg: When selected, JAWS states the cursor shape when it changes. This gives you useful information about what options are available. For example, an hour glass cursor indicates the system is busy and cannot respond to commands until the current task is completed. By default, this setting is not checked.

Controls.Label: &Text Caret Blink Rate
Controls.HelpMsg: This edit box allows you to specify a rate between 53 and 1000 milliseconds at which the cursor blinks on and off in application edit fields. The default value is 53 which is the fastest blink rate. The higher the value, the slower the cursor will blink in edit fields. In some applications, slowing it down could result in JAWS reporting wrong characters as you move quickly through text. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Mouse Click Tolerance
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine the exact position at which a mouse click is simulated when using keystrokes such as NUM PAD SLASH or NUM PAD STAR. The position is measured relative to the position of the JAWS cursor.

Controls.Label: Click T&olerance X
Controls.HelpMsg: This edit box specifies the number of pixels to the right of the JAWS cursor at which a mouse click is simulated. The default value is 1. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: &Click Tolerance Y
Controls.HelpMsg: This edit box specifies the number of pixels below the JAWS cursor at which a mouse click is simulated. The default value is -2. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Vertical Caret Dimensions
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine minimums and maximums for the height and width of vertical carets that JAWS recognizes. Vertical carets less than the minimums or greater than the maximums are not recognized.

Controls.Label: Minimum &Height
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to set the minimum height for the vertical caret. JAWS will not recognize vertical carets with a height less than this value. The default is 4 pixels. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Minimum &Width
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to set the minimum width for the vertical caret. JAWS will not recognize vertical carets with a width less than this value. The default is 1 pixel. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Maximum H&eight
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to set the maximum height for the vertical caret. JAWS will not recognize vertical carets with a height greater than this value. The default is 90 pixels. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Maximum W&idth
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to set the maximum width for the vertical caret. JAWS will not recognize vertical carets with a width greater than this value. The default is 3 pixels. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Horizontal Caret Dimensions
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to determine minimums and maximums for the height and width of horizontal carets that JAWS recognizes. Horizontal carets less than the minimums or greater than the maximums are not recognized.

Controls.Label: Minimum Hei&ght
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to set the minimum height for the horizontal caret. JAWS will not recognize horizontal carets with a height less than this value. The default is 1 pixel. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Minim&um Width
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to set the minimum width for the horizontal caret. JAWS will not recognize horizontal carets with a width less than this value. The default is 4 pixels. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Ma&ximum Height
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to set the maximum height for the horizontal caret. JAWS will not recognize horizontal carets with a height greater than this value. The default is 4 pixels. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Maximum Wi&dth
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this edit box to set the maximum width for the horizontal caret. JAWS will not recognize horizontal carets with a width greater than this value. The default is 14 pixels. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to enable smoother playing of WAV files when using the DEC Talk Access 32 software synthesizer. This is only valid in Default.jcf. Any changes take effect the next time you start JAWS.

Controls.Label: Allow &Wave Files with Software Synthesizers
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to enable smoother playing of WAV files when using the DEC Talk Access 32 software synthesizer. This option is only available in Default.jcf. Changes to this setting take effect the next time you start JAWS.  It is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: &Reset Frequency
Controls.HelpMsg: This edit box specifies how often JAWS resets the synthesizer. This value is measured in milliseconds.  For example, if this setting is 2000, JAWS only resets the synthesizer once every two seconds. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

HelpMsg: Use the option in this group to control when and how JAWS speaks individual punctuation marks. This option is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: &Customize Punctuation...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Customize Punctuation to open the Customize Punctuation dialog box. Use these items to control when and how JAWS speaks individual punctuation marks. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.   This setting is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: &Punctuation Level
Controls.HelpMsg: Select the level of punctuation you want to hear. Available options are None, Some, Most, and All. A higher level of punctuation can be helpful while proofreading or editing. Some users find a lower level causes less distraction for more casual reading. This setting is only available in the JAWS default settings (CTRL+SHIFT+D).

Controls.Label: Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

HelpMsg: A voice alias allows you to save any combination of person, pitch, and rate using a specific alias name. It can then be attached to one or more items. For example, you can create a voice alias with a deeper pitch than you normally use, and then associate it with bold text. JAWS then reads any bold text using the voice with the deeper pitch. Use the options in this group to create, modify, or delete voice aliases. These options are only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: Customize &Voice Aliases...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Customize Voice Aliases to open the Customize Voice Aliases dialog box. Use these items to save any combination of person, pitch, and rate as a voice alias. You can then associate this voice alias with one or more items that are read using the Speech and Sounds Schemes. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.  This setting is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

HelpMsg: A window class is a programming level label for a window or control. When non-standard class labels are used for edit boxes and check boxes, JAWS may not recognize these labels. Use the options in the Window Classes dialog box to assign standard labels to these windows and controls so that JAWS can readily access these items.

Controls.Label: Customize &Window Classes...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Customize Window Classes to open the Customize Window Classes dialog box. Use these items to assign standard class labels to windows and controls so that JAWS can more readily access them. This is most useful in programs where JAWS does not recognize controls such as edit fields or check boxes. Although the control may work the same as in other programs, it may have a different name. Assigning the standard name to such controls allows JAWS to read and work with them properly.  Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure the state of important keys used by JAWS. For example, this group controls the use of Navigation Quick Keys, the assignment of the JAWS modifier key (INSERT, CAPS LOCK, or SCROLL LOCK), the use of one or both INSERT keys, the state of the NUM LOCK key on start up, and other essential keyboard functions.

Controls.Label: Navigation &Quick Keys
Controls.HelpMsg: Navigation Quick Keys let you move through Web pages with easy to remember commands, such as T for table, F for form field, N for non link text, and V for visited link. These commands are only available when the Virtual Cursor is active. Use these radio buttons to set Navigation Quick Keys off, on, or on only during Say All reading. The default is on.

Controls.Label: JAWS Insert Key
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to select which INSERT key, the NUM PAD INSERT, the Extended INSERT, or both, to use as the JAWS modifier  key. The Extended keys are located between the NUM PAD and  the main keyboard body. Select both check boxes to use either INSERT key as the modifier key.

Controls.Label: Use &Numpad Insert
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to use the NUM PAD INSERT key as the JAWS INSERT key. It can then be used together with other keys to complete a JAWS keystroke. If it is cleared, pressing the NUM PAD INSERT key sends an Insert command to the current application. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Use &Extended Insert
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to use the Extended INSERT key as the JAWS INSERT key. It can then be used together with other keys to complete a JAWS keystroke. The Extended INSERT key is the top left key in the group of keys called the "six pack," between the number pad and the main body of keys on the keyboard. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: JAWS Key for Desktop &Layout
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to specify which key JAWS uses as a modifier to issue certain commands. For example, to read the title bar, you would press the key selected here, along with the letter T. Changes you make only affect the current keyboard layout. Select the INSERT, CAPS LOCK, or SCROLL LOCK key to use as the modifier key.  This setting is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: Initial state of Nu&mLock key
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to control whether or not the NUM LOCK key is enabled when JAWS starts. This option is only available in Default.jcf. The default is to turn off the NUM LOCK key when JAWS starts. This setting is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: Use &Unified Keyboard Processing Method
Controls.HelpMsg:
This is a new method for processing keystrokes that aims to bring consistency across all three products. In the future, it will help to avoid key conflicts and offer a better user experience for someone transitioning between Fusion, ZoomText, and JAWS. When this check box is selected, JAWS and Fusion will use the newer unified keyboard processor. Clearing this option uses legacy keyboard processing.
This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Use &Virtual Key Codes
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to have JAWS and Fusion use virtual key codes instead of scan codes when processing keystrokes. Using virtual key codes improves compatibility with alternative keyboard layouts such as DVORAK. This check box is cleared by default and is only available if the Use Unified Keyboard Processing Method option is enabled. After changing this option, you must restart JAWS or Fusion for the new setting to take affect.

Controls.Label: &Differentiate Between Numpad Keys and Extended Keys
Controls.HelpMsg: If this check box is selected, the NUM PAD keys and the Extended keys are treated as separate keys rather than as duplicate instances of the same keys. The Extended keys are the keys between the number pad and the main body of the keyboard, and are often referred to as the "six pack" or "inverted T." Once this check box is selected, you can use the check box options in the JAWS Insert Key group Keyboard Manager to assign different commands to these keys. For example, NUM PAD INSERT+UP ARROW and Extended INSERT+UP ARROW could be assigned to separate commands. By default, this check box is cleared.

Controls.Label: Di&fferentiate Between Left and Right Paired Keys
Controls.HelpMsg: Paired keys, which are the LEFT and RIGHT ALT, CTRL, and SHIFT keys, are used interchangeably. For example, if you change a keyboard assignment in Keyboard Manager, and press LEFT CTRL+INSERT+K, when you later activate the command, the LEFT or RIGHT CTRL key can be used as part of the keystroke. You may want to specify to differentiate between these keys when assigning hot keys to make more key combinations available to you. Select this check box to differentiate between the left and right instances of each paired key when making key assignments.   This check box is cleared by default.  This setting is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: Allow On &Screen Keyboards
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box if you want to use an on-screen keyboard with JAWS. When using this option, some programs that allow you to assign replacement text to keystrokes or automate typing (such as ShortKeys) may not work correctly. This setting is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: Manage Key Labels...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Manage Key Labels to open the Manage Key Labels dialog box. Use these items to specify which keyboard keys are echoed, and what name is echoed for each key. The Key Labels list shows the Key Name, which is the name of the key on the keyboard, the Key Label, which is the label that is echoed when you press the key, and the Mute Status, which indicates whether or not the key label is announced.  Select a Key Name from the list, and choose Toggle Mute to switch between mute and speak status, or choose Change Label to change the key's label.  Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

HelpMsg: Use the options in this group to configure advanced JAWS settings, such as Sleep Mode, the way JAWS reads prompts (control labels), the way the Virtual PC Cursor operates in HTML documents, and more.

Controls.Label: Sleep Mo&de
Controls.HelpMsg: Select to enable sleep mode, and turn off JAWS processing. This is used to automatically put JAWS to sleep within certain applications that have their own speech support, such as OpenBook.  This option is only available for specific applications and cannot be set for "Default/All Applications".

Controls.Label: S&earch for Prompts
Controls.HelpMsg: Use the radio buttons in this group to determine to what extent JAWS searches for prompts. Prompts are the labels for controls. With Minimum Search, JAWS reads the prompt only if it is next to the control. With Extended Search, JAWS reads the prompt if it is on the same line as the control. With Maximum Search, JAWS reads the prompt if it is on the same line as, or on the line directly above the control. The default selection is Maximum Search.

Controls.Label: &Text Out Delay
Controls.HelpMsg: This edit box specifies the number of milliseconds JAWS waits before speaking text newly written to the screen. The default value is 0. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: &Pixels Per Space
Controls.HelpMsg: JAWS often needs to estimate the number of blank spaces represented within a blank portion of a line. JAWS makes such estimates using the number of pixels specified in this edit box. The default value is 8. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Pi&xels Per Tab
Controls.HelpMsg: JAWS can estimate the number of tab spaces contained within a blank portion of a line. JAWS bases these estimates on the number of pixels specified in this edit box. The default value is 10. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: Left &Margin in Pixels
Controls.HelpMsg: JAWS ignores the distance specified in pixels from the left border of the window. This can prevent JAWS from misreading the left margin, and prevent JAWS from assuming there are spaces where there really are none. The default value is 0. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: &Underline Proximity
Controls.HelpMsg: This edit box specifies how far away an underline must be from the text for it to be considered an underline by JAWS. The default value is 0. Press F6 to move directly to the edit box to change this setting.

Controls.Label: MSAA M&ode
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this combo box to select one of the following MSAA modes: Automatic, Enhanced, or Classic. Select Automatic to use MSAA when it is appropriate for such menus. Normally you do not need to change to the Enhanced setting. If you know this application is MSAA enabled, changing this setting to Enhanced may give better results. This setting in combination with the Screen Echo setting of highlighted text may provide too much speech (double echo). If so, change the Screen Echo setting in the User Options dialog to "Echo no Text." Using this setting will not allow Window Class assignments to take effect as defined in the Window Classes dialog. Classic is known as JAWS Legacy MSAA handling. This setting in combination with the Screen Echo setting of highlighted text may provide too much speech (double echo). If so, change the Screen Echo setting in the User Options dialog to "Echo no Text." Using this setting will not allow Window Class assignments to take effect as defined in the Window Classes dialog.  This option is only available for specific applications and cannot be set for "Default/All Applications".

Controls.Label: Use &Virtual Ribbon Menu
Controls.HelpMsg: Select this check box to turn on the Virtual Ribbon Menu. When it is on, the Ribbon is organized and navigated using a traditional menu and submenu format. This is true for any application that uses Ribbon menus. This makes it easy to navigate using ARROW keys or first letter navigation. This option is only available when Default settings are selected in the Application combo box. It is unavailable for other application specific files that are loaded. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: U&se Virtual PC Cursor
Controls.HelpMsg: If this check box is selected, the Virtual PC cursor is used to read HTML documents. When using the Virtual PC cursor, Web pages and other HTML documents are read as if they were formatted into single columns, with each link or form field on a line of its own.  This mode allows you to navigate or select text in a Web page as if you were in a standard text document, while also giving you the ability to fill out forms or activate links. This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Virtual Cursor On/Off based on &Browser Tabs
Controls.HelpMsg:
When this check box is selected, JAWS remembers the current state of the Virtual Cursor when toggled using INSERT+Z for a tab in Google Chrome. For example, if you choose to turn the Virtual Cursor off in a web application such as GMail which offers a better user experience, and then you press CTRL+N or CTRL+T to open a web page in a new tab, the Virtual Cursor will be turned back on, but will remain off in GMail. This allows you to move focus back to GMail and not have to remember to disable the Virtual Cursor again. The Virtual Cursor reverts back to its default setting when you close the browser tab or restart JAWS.
Clearing this check box causes the Virtual Cursor to go back to the default setting when focus changes as it did in prior versions. For example, if you turn it off in GMail and then press ALT+TAB to move to another window, the Virtual Cursor will be turned back on when focus returns to GMail.
This check box is selected by default. For technical reasons, this feature only works in Chrome at this time.

Controls.Label: Start menu: A&ccess Out-of-Process
Controls.HelpMsg:
Select this check box if JAWS is not reading as you navigate the Windows 10 Start menu.
This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: Use Accessibility &Driver for Screen Capture
Controls.HelpMsg:
The accessibility driver is a system level driver installed by our software that has been used for many years to provide screen information to JAWS. This information is known as the Off Screen Model (OSM) and is used primarily by review cursors like the JAWS Cursor and Invisible Cursor as well as by JAWS scripts. As Windows 10 increasingly uses different methods of displaying information, this legacy accessibility driver no longer works in many cases.
Clearing this check box configures JAWS to use new API Accessibility Monitor technology we developed in order to help overcome the missing information previously obtained from the Accessibility Driver.
You can also assign a keystroke to the ToggleScreenCaptureMethod script using the Keyboard Manager to quickly toggle this setting.
This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Enable Accessible Notification Events
Controls.HelpMsg:
When this check box is selected, Windows generated accessible event notifications will be spoken and provided in Braille using Flash Messages. An example of where you will hear these types of notifications include certain areas in Microsoft Office, such as the Business Bars. If this check box is cleared, they will also not be shown in the Notification History (INSERT+SPACEBAR, N).
This check box is selected by default.

Controls.Label: Say Blank for Empty Edit
Controls.HelpMsg:
If this check box is selected, JAWS says "blank" when focus moves into an empty edit control and when INSERT+TAB is pressed to read the window prompt and text.
This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: T&rack Focus Rectangle
Controls.HelpMsg: This setting is required for programs that use a focus rectangle, such as Microsoft Excel. A focus rectangle is similar to a carat, but the focus is a rectangular area defined by line segments in the off screen model. This check box is selected by default. It is recommended that you do not change this setting.

Controls.Label: Notify about new &FSCasts
Controls.HelpMsg:
FSCast is Freedom Scientific's podcast featuring news, interviews, and product demonstrations relating to Freedom Scientific products.
Select this check box to have JAWS display a dialog box when a new FSCast episode is available. You can then choose whether to listen to the current episode, go to the FSCast web page to hear the current episode as well as prior episodes, or be reminded again later. Press ESC or choose OK to not be notified again until the next episode is available. Clear this check box to never receive FSCast notifications.
This option is off by default.

Controls.Label: A&nnounce Multiline Edit
Controls.HelpMsg: If this check box is selected, JAWS indicates when focus moves into a multiline edit field. This check box is cleared by default.

Controls.Label: Rely On MSAA for &Listviews
Controls.HelpMsg: By default, JAWS uses MSAA (Microsoft Active Accessibility) when it fails to read list views using the normal method. However, if you experience problems reading list views in a certain application, select this check box and see if this resolves the issue. JAWS will then read only the MSAA information for list views. Be sure that you select this check box in the application's configuration file. This option is only available for specific applications and cannot be set for "Default/All Applications".

Controls.Label: Subm&it Anonymous Usage Data
Controls.HelpMsg:
Select this check box if you would like to contribute your anonymous usage data to help us improve Freedom Scientific Products. Collected data includes JAWS version, operating system version, language, country, as well as information on various JAWS settings such as the current synthesizer, braille display, and braille table. No spoken or braille content is collected and no data is shared with any parties outside of Freedom Scientific.
This option is cleared by default.
Please note that certain connected features in your product may require this setting be checked.

Controls.Label: Error Reporting
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this group of radio buttons to specify whether or not JAWS sends error report files to Freedom Scientific. You can choose to have JAWS ask you each time if you want to send error reports, always send error reports, or never send error reports. By default, JAWS will ask each time if you want to send error reports.

Controls.Label: &Ask me if I want to send error reports to Freedom Scientific each time
Al&ways send error reports to Freedom Scientific
&Never send error reports to Freedom Scientific
&OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: Are you sure you want to add the colors white on navy as a custom highlight color?  \n\nPress ENTER to continue.   Press ESCAPE to cancel.
&OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

HelpMsg: Use the option in this group to change the default Research It lookup source, or add or remove a lookup source in the Research It list. This option is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

Controls.Label: Configure &Lookup...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Configure Lookup to open the Research It Options dialog box. Use it to set the default lookup source and to add or remove a lookup source from Research It. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box. From within this dialog box, select an item's check box so that it is available when you open Research It, which is done by pressing INSERT+SPACEBAR, R. If the check box is cleared, the lookup source will not be available.  This setting is only available in the "Default/All Applications" application.

The list box contains all lookup source items that are currently available to JAWS. Each item in the list has a check box. By default, all check boxes are selected. If you clear a check box, that item will not appear in the lookup list. For example, if you do not want CNN news stories to be available as a lookup item, just clear the CNN Headline News Stories check box. The next time you run Research It, CNN Headline News Stories will not appear in the lookup item list.

Controls.Label: Description
Controls.HelpMsg: Provides a brief description of the lookup source currently highlighted in the list.

Controls.Label: &Set Primary
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to set the lookup source that is currently selected in the list box as the default or primary lookup source. This is what determines which lookup source is automatically used when you press INSERT+WINDOWS Key+R.

Controls.Label: &OK
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to save changes and close the dialog box.

Controls.Label: &Cancel
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose this button to ignore changes and close the dialog box.

HelpMsg: Use the option in this group to control how JAWS responds to highlighted items. Windows uses highlights to set apart icons and menu items that have system focus. Text that is selected is also highlighted. The colors used for these highlights are set using Control Panel. Colors are also specified by some applications. JAWS reads the text of highlighted items and echoes changes to what is highlighted. For example, when using ARROW Keys to move through a menu, JAWS reads each menu item to which the highlight (or selection) is moved.

Controls.Label: Configure &Highlight Colors...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Configure Highlight Colors to open the Configure Highlight Colors dialog box. Use it to select which colors are recognized as highlights for applications. Highlights can be based on foreground color for text color, background color, or both. Once assigned, text that matches a specified color is treated as highlighted text. Note: The colors that are available are initially set using Windows Control Panel. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.

HelpMsg: A scheme is a set of rules defining how JAWS behaves when speaking controls, attributes, indentations, quoted materials, and many other forms of information. Use the options in this group to select, modify, create, or delete sound schemes.

Controls.Label: Active &Speech and Sounds Scheme
Controls.HelpMsg: Use this combo box to select one of several factory speech and sound schemes. Each scheme provides a unique reading behavior when it encounters formatting and text styles, proofreading styles, such as color, font, and attribute changes, and indentation formats. You can also start with a factory scheme and then customize it to your liking. Classic is the default speech and sounds scheme.

Controls.Label: Scheme &Description
Controls.HelpMsg: This list box provides a brief description of the selected speech and sounds scheme.

Controls.Label: &Modify Schemes ...
Controls.HelpMsg: Choose Modify Schemes to open the Modify Schemes dialog box. Use it to select and edit and save an existing speech and sounds scheme, rename a scheme, create a new scheme, or delete an existing scheme. Press SPACEBAR to open the dialog box.
